title: Ticket #7008: Terminate event missing from DAGMan job event log
description:
Stefano Belforte from CMS reports an incident where a job that's part of a DAG completes and leaves the queue, but there's no terminate event in the DAGMan event log. There is a terminate event in the corresponding user job event log.

Ticket in CRABServer issue tracker: https://github.com/dmwm/CRABServer/issues/5876
remarks:

2019-Apr-18 15:00:40 by jfrey:
Basic information:
  • Condor Version 8.6.13
  • Machine vocms0106.cern.ch
  • user cms1627
  • DAG job id 28708598.0
  • node job id 28720855.0
  • DAG node name Job5044

The user and dagman event log files are on local disk, in the same directory. No other events in the dagman event log have the same timestamp. The shadow daemon log has no errors related to the event log, and the shadow process continues normal operation after writing the terminate event.

Here are the events for the job:

  • 04/17 02:25:58 submit event
  • 04/17 02:45:57 execute event
  • 04/17 02:46:06 image size event
  • 04/17 02:51:07 image size event
  • 04/17 02:53:00 image size event
  • 04/17 02:53:02 terminate event (not in dagman log)

2019-Apr-26 14:22:30 by jfrey:
After examining the code, I see two explanations for the missing event:
  • Sometime between the writing of the execute and terminate events, something modified the memory location in the shadow holding the fd of the dagman log with a negative value. I see no legitimate code that would do this.
  • The write() syscall for writing to the dagman log returned a short write of 0 bytes. Documentation I've found online says this shouldn't happen (if the call is interrupted before any bytes are written, it should return -1), but some I/O drivers in the linux kernel might do it none-the-less.

The current log writing code flags an error if the write() call returns -1, but not if write() returns any non-negative value. We should change it so that any value less than the full size of the event indicates an error.

2019-Jul-03 11:58:59 by coatsworth:
CODE REVIEW

All looks good.
